reviewText:
RollerCoaster Tycoon 3: Platinum Edition is a theme park sim-tycoon game. You are put in charge of a your own theme parks which you must expand to bring more customers and money to them.

Pros: You have a large variety of rollercoasters, rides, kiosks and themed decorations to lay, often more than you'll be able to cram in a single map. You manage the finance by determining costs for rides, food and souvenirs, balancing against running costs, staff wages other expenses including research which allow you to access even more rides and objects for your park. You start your career with a short selection of maps and a few pre-made rollercoaster designs, and unlock more as you achieve goals in each locations. The Soaked! and Wild! expansions adds even more locations, rides and stalls, you can play the same map over and over yet build different parks every time! Many rides allow themed-customization as well, from color scheme to cart-style or train-length. Micromanagement can also be as deep as you want it: you can go as far as choosing how much pickles a specific burger stand puts in its 1/4-pounder, or don't bother with it, it's up to you.

Cons: The graphics are bad when zoomed in, from character designs to fixed-shadows under moving objects, graphical glitches including bad character animations or placement on rides. You can barely hear the music from your rides unless you're zoomed in almost all the way. Building rides has flaws, too: buying a pre-made rollercoaster design never explains why a location wouldn't work or what can be done to the landscape to make it fit, while other times the entire ride will get elevated multiple stories due to a single tile that's 1 pixel higher than the others. As the first game of the series to drop the genre's usual fix-isometric view for a 3D-engline, the camera controls can be extremely clunky, while the vertical angle resets every time you're trying to change it.

Verdict: ★★★★☆ - Next on your list!

If you like tycoon games, you're likely to enjoy this one. I could write a review 10 times as long and still have more to say about this game, so in a nutshell: perfect example of a tycoon game done right, with huge variety, good flexibility and excellent replayabiliy. I look forward to the final version of RollerCoaster Tycoon World, the next entry in the franchise!

reviewText:
Chris Sawyer, maker of 90s clasic Transport Tycoon 2 Deluxe, was part of this revamp of RCT2 that does not add much in terms of graphics. This third installment of the game was made by Atari with the intention to attract all ages and genders, so the game looks slightly childish in my opinion. But make no mistake - this simulation is so rich it would make your head explode.

The game features an incredible level of depth to the simulation, almost unparallaled. It allows you to control if/how much toppings you put in each beverage sold in one of the dozens of stalls. It includes cheap terrain modification (and spray paint) and many differently themed decorations and buildings. It has a scheduled fireworks simulator with a built in looper (and the cost is per single firework). Each sim in the park has a wallet, a set of hands to hold on to stuff, a set of bars for hunger/thirst/nausea and ride preferences. You will, at some point, be required to address the career ambitions of Animal Keeper 17.

And there's the rollercoaster simulator. Many dozens of real rollercoasters where the ride excitement is a factor of the speed, drops, g forces and more. A beatutifully complex and simple interface. I grew up playing the prequels and I was surprised every ride and rollercoaster I knew from the game was a real thing somewhere. RCT2 had missions in Six Flags parks and other famous parks around the world. This one instead has many creative scenarios where you start with a crazy looking old town or a huge garden that show you what this game has to offer if you decide to go sandbox.

Which is probably the point of this game - it's like building models more than anything.

Downsides are the low difficulty in this installment. If you are completing the missions you don't really need to use the many features of this game. I would give my Peeps a food stall only after three or four months. There's no benefit to tampering with the food and items you sell (the ride control boxes are awesome to tinker with).

Buy it on sale for sure.

reviewText:
First of all, bear in mind that my low steam playtime is just that. I used to beat the crap out of the game disc on my first laptop, so you can easily add 80 hours to the playtime.

Well, RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 is now an aging beast. The game originally released in 2004, and that unfortunally shows. While graphics isn't the main or even secondary reason you would like to play this game, there are some now hard to forgive kinks in that department like the lack of native 1080p support. There are of course workarounds to this, but then again, it's hard to blame a game from before widescreens became common to have widescreen support.

So, what about the game itself? Well, it's really as solid as you would expect the sequel to RCT2 would be.  While the iconic, isometric pixel art of the first two games have been replaced with 3D, it really looks good for its age. There is content enough in the game to keep you sucked in for a long, long time, plenty of RollerCoaster types and designs to keep you interested and best of all, the people in the park aren't as timid as they were in the first two games, allowing you to build more extreme rides without it having a negative impact on your play.

reviewText:
8.5/10 - RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 Platinum is a soiid collection and the definitve package for the RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 series, as it features the base game, plus both expansions. The expansion which add a tremendous amount of content to the game. RCT3 is at its core, a management game. You build and run a theme park the way you see fit, byt placing rides, attractions, booths, and more, to attract customers, and at the end, collecting their hard earned money to keep the park going, and to pay your employees their hard earned money. Obstacles will come in the form of rides breaking down, unhappy patrons or employees, and more problems to solve. And there are 2 ways to play this game: Full on simulation mode, where money matters, or a full on sandbox mode, where you can pretty much spend as much as you want, and get away with anything. There are as well, fun little scenarios to play to get you used to the games mechanics, which start off as tutorials, and end up being challenges to help you unlock stuff.

For anyone who has played RCT1 and 2, this game strays from the earlier isometric visuals of the first 2, and comes back with full 3D visuals, which this time around actually let you ride the park rides in 1st person. Everything looks pretty damn gorgeous, except for a few visual hiccups, like when messing with terrain, or the extremely aged and ugly looking patrons. Everything else looks damn fine though for a game this old. The expansions will take your vanilla park, and add a water park features, as well as a wildlife park, complete with various animals to use as attractions for the patrons.

This title is pretty easy to get into, even for people new to management games. Also a blast to play for veterans.

TL;DR: Everyone needs to give this game a shot.

Everyhting I can think of is there. There is over 35 roller coaster types, spanning a wide range of abilities and themes. My to favorites are the Corkscrew coaster, which allows you to go all twisty-turney all over the park, and the Stratocoaster which is hydraulic-powered and goes extremely fast.

The new CoasterCam ability allows you to ride your own coasters, which let me tell you is amazingly fun. You get to see your creation unfold in front of your very eyes, and that is very rewarding.

The game isn't just about roller coasters, there is a plethora of other rides and attractions. You can build pool slides, pools, ferris wheels, free-fall rides and swings, among much other attractions. You also have to manage food and drinks, or your guests (Peeps) will get hungry/thirsty.

You can individually manage the prices for each individual attraction, giving your park a good balance of money I/O.

CONS:

Bad Graphics (Not bad for 2004 though)
Game gets EXTREMELY laggy if you have a big park.
Building coasters is annoying sometimes as they sometimes fail and you have to re-build the entire thing.


But that's it!

9/10, amazing game!

reviewText:
So much, yet so little.

Atari/Frontier really needed to follow up on the title, but it can still be great fun. You'll notice the thousands of things they needed to include before ending the franchise. Worth every penny in my opinion though. I'm a sucker for theme parks and roller coasters. It just gets a little tiring hearing the same sounds and running into all the things that I can't do that should exist. This on top of some stupid bugs and ugly physics can leave you questioning the purpose of some features including in the title.

The primary issue with RCT3 is that it's outdated, yet still being pushed and played by the community because there hasn't been a game like it since it came out, so we're left with what we've got. If you're REALLY good at working with this title, you can modify it and submit your creations online to share and upload into the game, which is cool, but very tedious.

Overall, it's really fun game to expand your creativity, but if you're looking to create Disney/Universal quality attractions, it's not happening here. Theme Parks simply weren't what they are now back in 2004. You're getting what's advertised, but just be aware that you'll find yourself wanting so much more out of something with infinite potential. I just really wish there was money in rebooting the franchise to give us a fresh addtion. A new engine with realistic sounds and lifelike visuals sounds better than food... (joking)

There is a title is the works from a seperate company called Theme Park Studio, but it has yet to be released and may be a little too complex for the average consumer like myself. It has great potential and could become the closest thing we will get to another RCT. Cheers!

reviewText:
So much, yet so little.

Atari/Frontier really needed to follow up on the title, but it can still be great fun. You'll notice the thousands of things they needed to include before ending the franchise. Worth every penny in my opinion though. I'm a sucker for theme parks and roller coasters. It just gets a little tiring hearing the same sounds and running into all the things that I can't do that should exist. This on top of some stupid bugs and ugly physics can leave you questioning the purpose of some features including in the title.

The primary issue with RCT3 is that it's outdated, yet still being pushed and played by the community because there hasn't been a game like it since it came out, so we're left with what we've got. If you're REALLY good at working with this title, you can modify it and submit your creations online to share and upload into the game, which is cool, but very tedious.

Overall, it's really fun game to expand your creativity, but if you're looking to create Disney/Universal quality attractions, it's not happening here. Theme Parks simply weren't what they are now back in 2004. You're getting what's advertised, but just be aware that you'll find yourself wanting so much more out of something with infinite potential. I just really wish there was money in rebooting the franchise to give us a fresh addtion. A new engine with realistic sounds and lifelike visuals sounds better than food... (joking)

There is a title is the works from a seperate company called Theme Park Studio, but it has yet to be released and may be a little too complex for the average consumer like myself. It has great potential and could become the closest thing we will get to another RCT. Cheers!

reviewText:
You're actually reading reviews on a classic game like this?

Go buy it, jeez! It's totally worth it!
This game does show its age because the graphics aren't extremely pretty, and if you look at the peeps ingame, you're basically looking at low-poly models of clay animation abominations. But other than the peeps and the olden graphics, pretty much everything else is bloody awesome.

This is basically a game where you manage an amusement park. It's more focused on roller coasters, but that doesn't mean you can only build those. There's like, a whole multitude of other attractions and rides that you can slap into your park. Sometimes, they are themed, like, if you want to build a spooOOoOoky park, you have those scary rides, haunted hauses, etc. The roller coasters? Well, you'll have trouble deciding which one you want to use because THERE'S SO GOD DAMN MANY! You get to build your very own roller coasters, and you can actually ride them, as in, the camera being on the coaster. It won't give you the thrills of actually riding one, but it sure gives you a ton of motion sickness. Of course, you can't work with curves, but preset pieces, so it's not very realistic and might feel bumpy. You can still make a good coaster that way. Fun.

Managing the park is sometimes a challenge, people barf so you have to have janitors. Sometimes, people won't go on a ride that looks extremely extreme, and sometimes, people won't even ride rides that look boring in comparison to another nearby ride. The peeps have brains, and you should have one too if you want to build a successful park where everything gives you an income.

Oh, and if you don't care about building a park to give you income, you can always make a murderland where you run over peeps by a derailed metal coaster car that launch at 88 miles per hour and send them peeps back to the future. Can't say I haven't done that myself.

It's old, but it's a really good and classic game. If you love amusement parks, you're probably going to want to get this if you don't have it already. It's really fun. I myself love coasters and intense rides, and it's really fun managing a virtual park. The game is both fun as it is, and as a coaster murder simulator. It's up to you to decide how you play it.

reviewText:
I had a few friends rave about RollerCoaster Tycoon and decided to give it a try when it was on sale.  I played Sim Theme Park when I was younger and had a blast with it and I hoped that RollerCoaster Tycoon would fill that void.  I was wrong.  While this game boasts some serious depth with regards to how many different types of rollercoasters, rides, and scenery you can build, those items seem irrelevant while playing (they are just for you, the AI doesn't notice it too much) and don't make up for the game's basic functionality shortcomings.

The first problem I experienced was building a rollercoaster is a serious time investment.  While that is fun at first, I spent a very long time just trying to complete the circuit, which is arguably the least fun part of building a coaster.  Then I had to create the entrance and exit and found myself spending more time creating a working queue that fit with my coaster design yet still didn't attract enough riders to fill it even a quarter of the way up.

My trouble really stems from the user interface for RollerCoaster Tycoon.  All the buttons are quite cryptic (just tiny icons that you have to memorize.  For example, the guest list icon has a wrench on it, which is easily confused with the staff icon, which also has a wrench on it) and I was unable to easily find hotkeys for basic tasks such as deletion, which is a two click operation each time.  The escape key, which in most games just exits the last or top-most open menu, always prompts you whether to leave your current game.  It is as if the interface designers hadn't ever played other games and made their own independent system, putting the responsibility on the user to learn how to play.

The other half of my issues comes from excessive depth in construction.  As I said before, I must have spent an hour creating a path because I wasn't allowed to build it under certain segments of my coaster, while I could under other segments.  I do accept some blame for not thinking through my design, but I came from the Sim Theme Park universe, where I could have fun creating a rollercoaster and would spend more time making money from it than from building the entrances and exits.  This problem extends to shops and kiosks where if you don't toggle the auto-levelling" feature (which should arguably be toggled on by default)

reviewText:
I don't know what your idea of fun is when it comes to a simulator that lets you control your very own theme park. I don't know if you like to make things perfectly profitable and enjoy the simulation of being extremely successful or if you just want to wreak havoc in the park to your devilish excitement… One thing's for sure, though, it sure is a lot of fun and your imagination is the limit!

I can literally spend an entire day creating an awesome park and still not feel bored at all (until I have a creator's block, which doesn't happen a lot to me.)

If you feel creative to create a theme park that you've always dreamed about creating but don't have the money or real estate, this game is definitely for you!

A great sandbox game. Better (In my humble opinion) than RCT 1 and 2. The game by itself is great, and allows you to be as creative as you want, or rush to that milestone as quickly as possible.
If you are like me, and find good sandbox games to be a giant time sucking destroyer of relationships/ruiner of financial stability, then your in luck! Mods. Thats right, mods.
This game REALLY shines if you install mods. Allowing you to create replicas of Disneyland, Cedar point, or a moon base turned amusment park. You can (with some basic 3D modelling knowledge) create your own objects to be put in, or simply download off of the many 'warehouse' custom-scenery websites. If you are like me, you will spend more time searching the web (deeply) for mods then actually playing the game. You will run out of room on your harddrive, and your GPU's VRAM will scream in agony... All optional though. THIS TIME I'll be only getting a few basics and just playing the.... Wait... reviewText:
It was only a matter of time before this franchise got taken into the realm of 3D, and while many die-hard fans still prefer the old 2D graphics, this newest version of the game is better in my opinion, despite a few flaws.

RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 puts you in the shoes of an amusement park manager, gives you a stack of money and a plot of land, and asks you to complete missions of varying types. Mostly, this boils down to overcoming a handful of issues, like difficult starting terrain, low funding, etc. You build your park as you see fit (and as money and space will allow), and succeed or fail depending on how well the multitudes of virtual tourists who visit like your park.

More often than not, you'll usually end up getting your park to a stable economic condition, and then use the excess revenues to build massive, scary, dangerous roller coasters. But that's really what this series has always been about, right? The best part is that because of the 3D graphics, you can ride your own coasters from a first-person view. This easily makes the cost of admission worth it.

My biggest complaint with this game is that the missions tend to get a little monotonous. Once you overcome whatever hardship the current mission throws at you, you're left building the same park over and over, in an effort to gain more funds and meet the other victory conditions. It's fun, but it can get a little boring. I suspect that most people just like to play the game in sandbox mode, so maybe this isn't as big an issue for others as it is for me. It's certainly not enough for me to not recommend the game, anyhow.

For cheaper than a ticket to a real theme park, RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 is a pretty good virtual replacement. Even if it gets a little tedious at times.

reviewText:
Rollercoaster Tycoon...a huge part of my childhood.

I love these games. There's something about slowly building up your park from a cute little amusement park to a giant attention-grabbing attraction. The game progresses at the pace you play it, so you can race to become the most well-known park in the area, or you can slowly but surely increase your park's size until you're happy with it.

One of the main parts of the RCT games is the ability to design your own roller coasters. Not a lot has changed with that mechanic since the first game, but there have been improvements. One of the most memorable improvements to the games is that now, in this game, you can ride the coasters you build. This adds the extremely satisfying ability to virtually test every coaster you make, which makes crafting your own coasters even more rewarding.

This game also allows you to customize some of the peeps (customers) that visit your park. This is actually a pretty cool addition to the series, as it adds that nice little feeling you get when you recognize a familiar peep walking around in your park.

All in all, if you're not into managing simulation games, even when they're simplified, you might want to skip over this game. On the other hand, if you're looking for a fun game that will eat up your hours like a toddler eats cotton candy, or even want to try a new managing sim, then I highly recommend this title.
